I.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE FACILITY 
 
A.  Justification 
 
1.  The transaction TA facility will provide project preparation support to ongoing and ensuing 
mandates, covering 42 projects in developing member countries (DMCs) across different sectors, 
listed below. These mandates will require conduct of technical, financial, economic, and legal, 
fiscal and operational due diligence to assess bankability and structure the project for private 
sector investment. 
1.  Armenia Urban Project  23. Pacific Urban Project 
2.  Bangladesh Health Project  24. Pacific Transport Project 
3.  Bangladesh Port Project  25. Pakistan Power Project 
4.  Bangladesh Road Project*  26. Pakistan Road Project 
5.  Cambodia Urban Project  27. Pakistan Urban Project 
6.  Cambodia Energy Project  28. Philippines ICT Project* 
7.  Cambodia Transport Project  29. Philippines Transport Project 
8.  India Urban Project  30. Philippines Urban Project 
9.  Indonesia Health  Project  31. Philippines Energy Project 
10. Indonesia Urban Project  32. PRC Health Project* 
11. Kazakhstan Road Project  33. PRC Urban Project 
12. Kazakhstan Urban Project  34. Thailand Urban Project 
13. Laos Urban Project  35. Thailand Energy Project* 
14. Laos Energy Project  36. Thailand Transport Project 
15. Laos Transport Project  37. Uzbekistan District Heating Project*  
16. Myanmar Urban Project  38. Uzbekistan Power Project 
17. Myanmar Energy Project  39. Uzbekistan Water Project* 
18. Myanmar Transport Project  40. Viet Nam Energy Project 
19. Mongolia Urban Project  41. Viet Nam Urban Project 
20. Mongolia Energy Project  42. Viet Nam Transport Project 
21. Mongolia Transport Project   
22. Pacific Energy Project        *ongoing project 
 
 
2.  The provision of ADB transaction advisory service in the DMCs mentioned above is 
expected to increase private sector participation in the provision of infrastructure assets and 
services. Under Strategy 2030, ADB will expand its support for PPPs by providing transaction 
advisory services largely through OPPP and assisting in project development, structuring, and 
preparation. As a project developer, ADB will scale up its transaction advisory services to help 
many public sector clients structure PPPs and develop robust and bankable project pipelines.  
 
3.  As of 30 June 2019, OPPP is implementing 11 mandates in energy, health, transport and 
urban sectors and has successfully closed four transaction advisory mandates. OPPP is actively 
pursuing mandates in several DMCs and is expected to secure three new mandates annually until 
2021. 
 
4.  Development of the above projects are in line with ADB Strategy 2030, which promotes 
infrastructure  investments  in  transport,  energy  and  urban  development,  and  encourages 
interventions in social sectors, such as education and health. The above projects are also in line 
with sectoral priorities of each of the DMC’s Country Partnership Strategies (CPS) / Country 
Operations Business Plans (COBP).

5.  Processing a TRTA for several projects is preferred against processing various individual 
TRTAs as this reduces the administrative burden of processing multiple TAs and allows flexibility 
to readily draw on funds as soon the need arises for any of the projects covered. OPPP prefers 
to avoid the situation wherein TA funds are tied up with projects that are delayed and cannot be 
used for other projects that already need funding.

7   
 
Outputs and Activities  
 
6.  Output  1:  Advisory  services  for  the  preparation  and  structuring  of  bankable  PPP 
transactions provided. Output 1 will include conduct of technical studies to provide information 
needed to finalize the technical parameters of the project and project agreements and address 
key obligations of the government under the agreements. Specific studies will be determined 
based on the underlying transaction. This will also include provision of financial and economic 
analysis support to DMCs, including value-for-money analysis, fiscal risk assessments, a financial 
model prepared in support for the proposed transaction structure, shadow bid models, and a final 
financial model that integrates the risk positions and financial structure of the project agreed 
between the government and the preferred bidder. In addition to development of these models, 
financial analysis support also includes review of the preferred bidder’s financial model and other 
financial analysis tasks as may be required for a transaction. 
 
7.  Output 2: Project marketing support provided. This may include provision of support to 
DMCs to retain providers of transaction support services, including but not limited to, translation 
services, data room management, organizing bidder conferences and other events, developing 
marketing materials, and advertising transactions through international media outlets. 
 
8.  Output 3: Support to drafting of project agreements and managing the bidding process 
provided. The TA will assist ADB in the conduct of a legal due diligence and ensure that 
appropriate legal inputs (from both international law and local law perspectives) are identified and 
incorporated  in  the  project  agreements,  and  that  the  content  and  structure  of  the  project 
agreements are consistent with best international standards. Project agreements are expected to 
include a concession agreement and other supporting agreements as required by the particular 
project  or  sector.  Assistance  and  advice  will  also  be  provided  to  the  government  during 
negotiations with the bidders.  
 
9.  Other support as needed. In addition to the forms of support mentioned above, the 
specifics of a transaction may require specialist inputs in areas including insurance, tax, geology, 
environment, social safeguards, independent audit of financial models, and other specialist inputs 
as may be required for a transaction.  
 
B.  Cost and Financing 
 
10.  The TA facility is estimated to cost $5.00 million, of which $3.08 will be financed from 
TASF 6 and $1.92 will be financed from TASF-Others. The key expenditure items are listed in 
Appendix 1. The TA facility will be subject to arrangements that will seek partial recovery of the 
amount financed under the TA facility. Terms of recovery are negotiated and vary for each project. 
Aside from a success fee upon achieving commercial close, there could also be a partial recovery 
upon achieving certain milestones (e.g. delivery of a due diligence report). 
 
11.  The government may provide counterpart support in the form of counterpart staff, office 
space, and other support, as articulated in the TAS agreement between ADB and the relevant 
government agency. The government will be informed that approval of the TA does not commit 
ADB to finance any ensuing project. 
 
C.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
12.  The TA activities for an ensuing mandate will start only after the TAS mandate letter has 
been signed between ADB and the client government.

8   
 
13.  ADB will be the executing and implementing agency of the TA. The TA will finance 
consulting services, workshop and training events, including study visits and resource persons; 
preparation of reports as well as communication, miscellaneous administration and support costs.

15.  Consulting services. ADB will engage the consultants following the ADB Procurement 
Policy (2017, as amended from time to time) and its associated project administration instructions 
and/or staff instructions.1  
 
16.  ADB’s procurement. Procurement will follow the ADB Procurement Policy (2017, as 
amended from time to time) and Procurement Regulations for ADB Borrowers (2017, as amended 
from time to time).  
 
 
II.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION  
 
17.  The President acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $5 million on a grant basis for 
the Transaction Advisory Services for the Preparation of Public–Private Partnership Projects in 
Asia.
